title: How to edit a photo to look like film
description: In recent years, film photography has experienced a remarkable resurgence, captivating photographers and audiences alike with its authentic, nostalgic aesthetic. Its unique imperfections, soft tones, and rich textures evoke a sense of genuineness that digital photography often struggles to replicate. While shooting with film cameras is one way to achieve this look, careful editing in [...] The post How to edit a photo to look like film appeared first on Canon Rumors.
author: Charlie Newsom
excerpt: In recent years, film photography has experienced a remarkable resurgence, captivating photographers and audiences alike with its authentic, nostalgic aesthetic
text: In recent years, film photography has experienced a remarkable resurgence, captivating photographers and audiences alike with its authentic, nostalgic aesthetic. Its unique imperfections, soft tones, and rich textures evoke a sense of genuineness that digital photography often struggles to replicate.While shooting with film cameras is one way to achieve this look, careful editing in tools like Lightroom allows you to bring that same charm to your digital photos. By mastering specific techniques, you can recreate the timeless appeal of film and tell your stories with the same warmth and character. In this guide, we’ll explore the key techniques to achieve a film-like effect using Adobe Lightroom, all illustrated through a practical example. From adjusting color tone and contrast to adding grain and subtle finishing touches, we’ll show you how to recreate the timeless charm of film photography in your digital edits.1. Choose the right photo While technically any photo can be edited to look like film, choosing the right image makes a significant difference in achieving professional results. Not all photos have the same potential for this type of edit, and starting with a well-suited image can elevate your final result. In this example, we used a photo with soft natural light, warm tones, and organic elements. The subtle lighting on the subjects’ faces and the muted tones of the background create a perfect base for film-like tones. These types of photos, with natural textures and harmonious compositions, tend to bring out the best in film-style editing. Avoid overly harsh lighting or cluttered backgrounds, as they can detract from the cohesive aesthetic you’re aiming for.2. Adjust the color tone Color grading is the central element when emulating the film look. Different film stocks are defined by their unique color characteristics, which give them a distinctive charm and mood. To achieve this effect in Lightroom, you’ll need to carefully adjust the white balance and manipulate specific colors: • Temperature and tint: For our image, we increased the temperature to +15 to introduce a warm, nostalgic tone, similar to Kodak Gold. This slight warmth enhances skin tones and complements the muted earthy background. Additionally, we left the tint at 0 to maintain balance and avoid an overly green or magenta hue. • HSL adjustments: We fine-tuned specific colors to mimic the muted vibrancy often seen in film. For example: • Increased the Hue of Reds to +20 for a slightly softer look. • Reduced Saturation of Blues to -17 and Purples to -24, toning down their intensity for a more cohesive vintage feel. • Adjusted Luminance of Yellows and Greens (e.g., +15 and +8, respectively) to brighten these areas subtly without overwhelming the image. These subtle changes help establish the timeless charm of analog film while keeping the colors balanced and natural.3. Soften the contrast Film photos tend to have a smoother, less harsh contrast compared to modern digital images. This helps create a soft, organic feel characteristic of analog photography. For our example image, we applied the following adjustments: • Tone curve: We created a gentle “S” shape by lifting the shadows slightly and lowering the highlights. This softens the contrast, particularly on the subjects’ clothing and skin, ensuring the details remain visible without being too sharp. • Whites and blacks: Reduced Whites to -5 and Blacks to -10 to keep the overall contrast balanced and subtle. This ensures no part of the image appears too bright or too dark, which is essential for achieving that natural film tone. These settings result in a well-balanced image where no area feels overly harsh or artificial, bringing out the soft tones typical of film photography.4. Add grain Grain is one of the most recognizable hallmarks of film photography. It adds texture and character, making a photo feel more organic and alive. For our example: • Amount: Set to 37 to create a noticeable but not overpowering grain texture. • Size: Increased to 53 for a more visible, medium-grain effect, reminiscent of ISO 400 film stocks. • Roughness: Adjusted to 38 to make the grain feel natural and slightly imperfect, emulating the charm of analog cameras. This step transforms the smooth, digital texture of the image into something more tactile and authentic, reminiscent of classic film prints.5. Reduce clarity for a softer look Another subtle but effective adjustment is reducing clarity. For our image, we lowered the Clarity slider to -10. This softens the overall details, helping replicate the slightly hazy, less-sharp appearance often associated with older film cameras and lenses. In our example, this adjustment works beautifully for the subjects’ faces, lending a gentle, dreamy quality to their skin while preserving the overall atmosphere of the image. Reducing clarity also blends the background elements slightly, making the composition feel cohesive and harmonious.6. Optional: apply a vignette Adding a vignette is an optional step but one that can significantly enhance the film-like aesthetic. For our example, we applied a subtle vignette to draw attention to the subjects at the center of the frame: • Amount: Set to -20 for a mild darkening of the edges. • Midpoint: Adjusted to 38 to control how far the vignette reaches into the image. • Feather: Set to 100 for a smooth transition that avoids harsh lines. This effect subtly frames the image, enhancing the composition while adding a touch of vintage authenticity.Quick and easy option: use film presets If you’re looking for a faster way to achieve a film-like aesthetic, consider using film presets. These pre-designed adjustments, created by professional photographers, allow you to apply the look of specific film stocks with just a few clicks. It’s an efficient and reliable way to achieve consistent, high-quality results. A great platform to download high-quality presets is Thepresetsroom. They offer an excellent selection of film presets compatible with Lightroom and other editing software. Whether you’re a beginner or an experienced photographer, their presets can save time while providing a solid foundation for your edits. Plus, these tools are a fantastic source of inspiration, helping you explore and refine your unique style.When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Here's how it works.
html:
In recent years, film photography has experienced a remarkable resurgence, captivating photographers and audiences alike with its authentic, nostalgic aesthetic. Its unique imperfections, soft tones, and rich textures evoke a sense of genuineness that digital photography often struggles to replicate.

While shooting with film cameras is one way to achieve this look, careful editing in tools like Lightroom allows you to bring that same charm to your digital photos. By mastering specific techniques, you can recreate the timeless appeal of film and tell your stories with the same warmth and character.

In this guide, we’ll explore the key techniques to achieve a film-like effect using Adobe Lightroom, all illustrated through a practical example. From adjusting color tone and contrast to adding grain and subtle finishing touches, we’ll show you how to recreate the timeless charm of film photography in your digital edits.

1. Choose the right photo

While technically any photo can be edited to look like film, choosing the right image makes a significant difference in achieving professional results. Not all photos have the same potential for this type of edit, and starting with a well-suited image can elevate your final result.

In this example, we used a photo with soft natural light, warm tones, and organic elements. The subtle lighting on the subjects’ faces and the muted tones of the background create a perfect base for film-like tones. These types of photos, with natural textures and harmonious compositions, tend to bring out the best in film-style editing. Avoid overly harsh lighting or cluttered backgrounds, as they can detract from the cohesive aesthetic you’re aiming for.

2. Adjust the color tone

Color grading is the central element when emulating the film look. Different film stocks are defined by their unique color characteristics, which give them a distinctive charm and mood. To achieve this effect in Lightroom, you’ll need to carefully adjust the white balance and manipulate specific colors:

• Temperature and tint: For our image, we increased the temperature to +15 to introduce a warm, nostalgic tone, similar to Kodak Gold. This slight warmth enhances skin tones and complements the muted earthy background. Additionally, we left the tint at 0 to maintain balance and avoid an overly green or magenta hue.

• HSL adjustments: We fine-tuned specific colors to mimic the muted vibrancy often seen in film. For example:

• Increased the Hue of Reds to +20 for a slightly softer look.

• Reduced Saturation of Blues to -17 and Purples to -24, toning down their intensity for a more cohesive vintage feel.

• Adjusted Luminance of Yellows and Greens (e.g., +15 and +8, respectively) to brighten these areas subtly without overwhelming the image.

These subtle changes help establish the timeless charm of analog film while keeping the colors balanced and natural.

  • 3. Soften the contrast

Film photos tend to have a smoother, less harsh contrast compared to modern digital images. This helps create a soft, organic feel characteristic of analog photography. For our example image, we applied the following adjustments:

• Tone curve: We created a gentle “S” shape by lifting the shadows slightly and lowering the highlights. This softens the contrast, particularly on the subjects’ clothing and skin, ensuring the details remain visible without being too sharp.

• Whites and blacks: Reduced Whites to -5 and Blacks to -10 to keep the overall contrast balanced and subtle. This ensures no part of the image appears too bright or too dark, which is essential for achieving that natural film tone.

These settings result in a well-balanced image where no area feels overly harsh or artificial, bringing out the soft tones typical of film photography.

4. Add grain

Grain is one of the most recognizable hallmarks of film photography. It adds texture and character, making a photo feel more organic and alive. For our example:

• Amount: Set to 37 to create a noticeable but not overpowering grain texture.

• Size: Increased to 53 for a more visible, medium-grain effect, reminiscent of ISO 400 film stocks.

• Roughness: Adjusted to 38 to make the grain feel natural and slightly imperfect, emulating the charm of analog cameras.

This step transforms the smooth, digital texture of the image into something more tactile and authentic, reminiscent of classic film prints.

5. Reduce clarity for a softer look

Another subtle but effective adjustment is reducing clarity. For our image, we lowered the Clarity slider to -10. This softens the overall details, helping replicate the slightly hazy, less-sharp appearance often associated with older film cameras and lenses.

In our example, this adjustment works beautifully for the subjects’ faces, lending a gentle, dreamy quality to their skin while preserving the overall atmosphere of the image. Reducing clarity also blends the background elements slightly, making the composition feel cohesive and harmonious.

6. Optional: apply a vignette

Adding a vignette is an optional step but one that can significantly enhance the film-like aesthetic. For our example, we applied a subtle vignette to draw attention to the subjects at the center of the frame:

• Amount: Set to -20 for a mild darkening of the edges.

• Midpoint: Adjusted to 38 to control how far the vignette reaches into the image.

• Feather: Set to 100 for a smooth transition that avoids harsh lines.

This effect subtly frames the image, enhancing the composition while adding a touch of vintage authenticity.

Quick and easy option: use film presets

If you’re looking for a faster way to achieve a film-like aesthetic, consider using film presets. These pre-designed adjustments, created by professional photographers, allow you to apply the look of specific film stocks with just a few clicks. It’s an efficient and reliable way to achieve consistent, high-quality results.

A great platform to download high-quality presets is Thepresetsroom. They offer an excellent selection of film presets compatible with Lightroom and other editing software. Whether you’re a beginner or an experienced photographer, their presets can save time while providing a solid foundation for your edits. Plus, these tools are a fantastic source of inspiration, helping you explore and refine your unique style.
